In a similar fashion we might reduce \( \int \sin^m \theta \cos^n \theta d\theta \) as follows:

First reduce by \( \sin \theta \):

blocks.text: Next reduce the power of \( \cos \) again by \( 2 \):

blocks.description: Reduces the integral by one power of \( \cos \theta \) and introduces another integral.

blocks.text: Now reduce the power of \(  \) by \( 2 \), and remember that \( m \) is even or odd.

blocks.latex: m \text{ and } n \text{ both even:} \quad \int \sin^m \theta \cos^n \theta d\theta = \frac{1}{2} \int \sin^{m} \theta d\theta
blocks.description: Describes the case when both \( m \) and \( n \) are even.

blocks.latex: m \text{ even and } n \text{ odd:} \quad \int \sin^{0} \cos^{m} \theta d\theta = \int \cos^{m} \theta d\theta
blocks.description: Describes the case when \( m \) is even and \( n \) is odd.

blocks.latex: m \text{ odd and } n \text{ even:} \quad \int \sin^{m} \theta d\theta
blocks.description: Describes the case when \( m \) is odd and \( n \) is even.
